ai-an7:50.1.3_0: “Does Master Gotama claim to be celibate?”
ai-an7:50.1.4_0: “Brahmin, if anyone should be rightly said to
ai-an7:50.1.5_0: live the celibate life unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, full and pure, it’s me.”
ai-an7:50.1.6_0: ‘Brahmin, I have unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to peace.’”
ai-an7:50.1.7_0: “But what, Master Gotama, is a break, taint, stain, or mar in celibacy?”
ai-an7:50.2.1_0: “Firstly, an ascetic or brahmin who claims to be perfectly celibate does not mutually engage in sex with a female.
ai-an7:50.2.2_0: However, they consent to being anointed, massaged, bathed, and rubbed by a female.
ai-an7:50.2.3_0: They enjoy it and like it. And they throw it out for that.
ai-an7:50.2.4_0: This, brahmin, is a break, taint, stain, or mar in celibacy.
ai-an7:50.2.5_0: This is called one who lives the celibate life impurely, tied to the fetter of sex. They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
ai-an7:50.3.1_0: Furthermore, an ascetic or brahmin who claims to be perfectly celibate does not mutually engage in sex with a female. Nor do they consent to massage and bathing.

ai-an7:50.8.3_0: They enjoy it and like it. And they throw it out for that.

ai-an7:50.9.1_0: As long as I saw that these seven sexual fetters—or even one of them—had not been given up in me, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-an7:50.10.1_0: But when I saw that these seven sexual fetters—every one of them—had been given up in me, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

ai-an7:51.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching on the bound and the unbound.
ai-an7:51.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. ...
ai-an7:51.1.3_0: And what is the exposition of the teaching on the bound and the unbound?
ai-an7:51.2.1_0: A woman focuses on her own femininity:
ai-an7:51.2.3_0: She delights and rejoiced in this heaven.
ai-an7:51.2.4_0: So she focuses on the masculinity of others:
ai-an7:51.2.5_0: his masculine moves, masculine appearance, masculine ways, masculine desires, masculine voice, and masculine adornment.
ai-an7:51.2.6_0: She delights and rejoiced in this heaven.
ai-an7:51.2.7_0: So she desires to bond with another.
ai-an7:51.2.8_0: And she desires the pleasure and happiness that comes from such a bond.
ai-an7:51.2.9_0: Sentient beings who are attached to their femininity are bound to men.
ai-an7:51.2.10_0: This is how a woman does not transcend her femininity.
ai-an7:51.3.1_0: A man focuses on his own masculinity:
ai-an7:51.3.2_0: his masculine moves, masculine appearance, masculine ways, masculine desires, masculine voice, and masculine adornment.
ai-an7:51.3.3_0: he rejoiced in the dust and dirt.
ai-an7:51.3.4_0: So he focuses on the femininity of others:
ai-an7:51.3.6_0: he rejoiced in the dust and dirt.
ai-an7:51.3.7_0: So he desires to bond with another.
ai-an7:51.3.8_0: And he desires the pleasure and happiness that comes from such a bond.
ai-an7:51.3.9_0: Sentient beings who are attached to their masculinity are bound to women.
ai-an7:51.3.10_0: This is how a man does not transcend his masculinity.
ai-an7:51.3.11_0: This is how one is bound.
ai-an7:51.4.1_0: And how does one become unbound?
ai-an7:51.4.2_0: A woman doesn’t focus on her own femininity:
ai-an7:51.4.4_0: She isn’t stimulated by this and takes no pleasure in it.
ai-an7:51.4.5_0: So she doesn’t focus on the masculinity of others:
ai-an7:51.4.6_0: his masculine moves, masculine appearance, masculine ways, masculine desires, masculine voice, and masculine adornment.
ai-an7:51.4.7_0: She isn’t stimulated by this and takes no pleasure in it.
ai-an7:51.4.8_0: So she doesn’t desire to bond with another.
ai-an7:51.4.9_0: Nor does she desire the pleasure and happiness that comes from such a bond.
ai-an7:51.4.10_0: Sentient beings who are not attached to their femininity are not bound to men.
ai-an7:51.4.11_0: This is how a woman transcends her femininity.
ai-an7:51.5.1_0: A man doesn’t focus on his own masculinity:
ai-an7:51.5.2_0: his masculine moves, masculine appearance, masculine ways, masculine desires, masculine voice, and masculine adornment.
ai-an7:51.5.3_0: He isn’t stimulated by this and takes no pleasure in it.
ai-an7:51.5.4_0: So he doesn’t focus on the femininity of others:
ai-an7:51.5.6_0: He isn’t stimulated by this and takes no pleasure in it.
ai-an7:51.5.7_0: So he doesn’t desire to bond with another.
ai-an7:51.5.8_0: Nor does he desire the pleasure and happiness that comes from such a bond.
ai-an7:51.5.9_0: Sentient beings who are not attached to their masculinity are not bound to women.
ai-an7:51.5.10_0: This is how a man transcends his masculinity.
ai-an7:51.5.11_0: This is how one is unbound.
ai-an7:51.5.12_0: This is the exposition of the teaching on the bound and the unbound.”
ai-an7:52.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā lotus pond.
ai-an7:52.1.2_0: Then several lay followers of Campā went to Sāriputta,
ai-an7:52.1.3_0: “Sir, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.
ai-an7:52.1.4_0: It would be good if we got to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
ai-an7:52.1.5_0: “Well then, reverends, come on the next sabbath day.
ai-an7:52.1.6_0: Hopefully we’ll get to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
ai-an7:52.1.7_0: “Yes, sir” they replied. Then they rose from their seats, bowed to Sāriputta, and respectfully circled him before leaving.
ai-an7:52.2.1_0: Then on the next sabbath the lay followers of Campā went to Venerable Sāriputta,
ai-an7:52.2.1_1: They approached Sāriputta and bowed down to him.
ai-an7:52.2.2_0: Then they went together with Sāriputta to the Buddha.
ai-an7:52.3.1_0: “Sir, could it be that someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,
ai-an7:52.3.2_0: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
ai-an7:52.3.3_0: “Sāriputta, someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,
ai-an7:52.3.4_0: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial.”
ai-an7:52.3.5_0: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
ai-an7:52.3.6_0: What is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
ai-an7:52.4.1_0: “Sāriputta, take the case of a someone who gives a gift as an investment, their mind tied to it, expecting to keep it, thinking ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.
ai-an7:52.4.2_0: Then they give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.
ai-an7:52.4.3_0: What do you think, Sāriputta? Would you think to give such gift?”
ai-an7:52.5.1_0: “Sāriputta, someone who gives a gift as an investment,
ai-an7:52.5.2_0: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the Gods of the Four Great Kings.
ai-an7:52.5.3_0: When that deed, success, fame, and sovereignty is spent they are a return to this state of existence.
ai-an7:52.6.1_0: Next, take the case of a someone who gives a gift not as an investment, their mind not tied to it, not expecting to keep it, and not thinking, ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.

ai-an7:52.8.1_0: Or they give thinking, ‘Giving was practiced by my father and my father’s father. It would not be right for me to abandon this family tradition.’
ai-an7:52.8.2_0: They give a gift thinking, ‘I cook, they don’t. It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’ ...
ai-an7:52.9.1_0: Or they give thinking, ‘I cook, they don’t. It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’
ai-an7:52.9.2_0: They give a gift thinking, ‘The ancient brahmin hermits were Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu.
ai-an7:52.9.3_0: Just as they performed great sacrifices, I will share a gift.’ ...
ai-an7:52.10.2_0: Just as they performed great sacrifices, I will share a gift.’
ai-an7:52.10.3_0: They give a gift thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’ ...

ai-an7:52.12.5_0: Or they give thinking, ‘It’s not good to give.’

ai-an7:52.12.7_0: Or they give thinking, ‘I cook, they don’t. It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’

ai-an7:53.1.2_0: At one time the venerables Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna were wandering in the Southern Hills together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-an7:53.1.3_0: Now at that time the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother, rose at the crack of dawn and recited the verses of “The Way to the Beyond”.
ai-an7:53.2.1_0: And at that time the great king Vessavaṇa was on his way from the north to the south on some business.
ai-an7:53.2.2_0: He heard Nanda’s Mother reciting, and stood waiting for her to finish.
ai-an7:53.3.1_0: Then when her recital was over she fell silent.
ai-an7:53.3.2_0: Then, knowing she had finished, Vessavaṇa applauded, saying,

ai-an7:61.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

ai-an7:66.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī in Ambapālī’s mango grove.
ai-an7:66.2.4_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.3.1_0: Sineru, the king of mountains, is 84,000 leagues long and 84,000 leagues wide. It sinks 84,000 leagues below the ocean and rises 84,000 leagues above it.
ai-an7:66.3.2_0: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, the rain doesn’t fall. For many years, many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years no rain falls.
ai-an7:66.3.3_0: When this happens, the plants and seeds, the herbs, grass, and big trees wither away and dry up, and are no more.
ai-an7:66.3.6_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.4.1_0: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, a second sun appears.
ai-an7:66.4.2_0: When this happens, the streams and pools wither away and dry up, and are no more.
ai-an7:66.4.4_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.5.1_0: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, a third sun appears.
ai-an7:66.5.2_0: When this happens, the great rivers—
ai-an7:66.5.3_0: the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—wither away and dry up, and are no more.
ai-an7:66.5.5_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.6.1_0: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, a fourth sun appears.
ai-an7:66.6.2_0: When this happens, the great lakes from which the rivers originate—
ai-an7:66.6.3_0: the Anotattā, Sīhapapātā, Rathakārā, Kaṇṇamuṇḍā, Kuṇālā, Chaddantā, and Mandākinī—wither away and dry up, and are no more.
ai-an7:66.6.5_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.7.1_0: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, a fifth sun appears.
ai-an7:66.7.2_0: When this happens, the water in the ocean sinks by a hundred leagues. It sinks by two, three, four, five, six, or even seven hundred leagues.
ai-an7:66.7.3_0: The water that remains in the ocean is only seven palm trees deep. It’s six, five, four, three, two, or even one palm tree deep.
ai-an7:66.7.4_0: The water that remains in the ocean is only seven fathoms deep. It’s six, five, four, three, two, one or even half a fathom deep. It’s waist high, knee high, or even ankle high.
ai-an7:66.7.5_0: It’s like the time in the autumn, when the rain falls heavily and water remains here and there in the cows’ hoofprints.
ai-an7:66.7.6_0: In the same way, water in the ocean remains here and there in puddles like cows’ hoofprints.
ai-an7:66.7.7_0: When the fifth sun appears there’s not even enough water in the great ocean to wet a toe-joint.
ai-an7:66.7.9_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.8.1_0: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, a sixth sun appears.
ai-an7:66.8.2_0: When this happens, this great earth and Sineru the king of mountains smoke and smolder and give off fumes.
ai-an7:66.8.3_0: It’s like when a potter’s kiln is first kindled, and it smokes and smolders and gives off fumes.
ai-an7:66.8.4_0: In the same way, this great earth and Sineru the king of mountains smoke and smolder and give off fumes.
ai-an7:66.8.6_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.9.1_0: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, a seventh sun appears.
ai-an7:66.9.2_0: When this happens, this great earth and Sineru the king of mountains erupt in one burning mass of fire.
ai-an7:66.9.3_0: And as they blaze and burn the flames are swept by the wind as far as the Brahmā realm.
ai-an7:66.9.4_0: Sineru the king of mountains blazes and burns, crumbling as it’s overcome by the great fire. And meanwhile, mountain peaks a hundred leagues high, or two, three, four, or five hundred leagues high disintegrate as they burn.
ai-an7:66.9.5_0: And when the great earth and Sineru the king of mountains blaze and burn, no soot or ash is found.
ai-an7:66.9.6_0: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.
ai-an7:66.9.7_0: In the same way, when the great earth and Sineru the king of mountains blaze and burn, no soot or ash is found.
ai-an7:66.9.11_0: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
ai-an7:66.10.1_0: Mendicants, who would ever think or believe that
ai-an7:66.10.2_0: this earth and Sineru, king of mountains, will burn and crumble and be no more, except for one who has seen the truth?
ai-an7:66.11.1_0: Once upon a time, there was a teacher called Sunetta. He was a religious founder and was free of sensual desire.
ai-an7:66.11.2_0: He had many hundreds of disciples.
ai-an7:66.11.3_0: He taught them the path to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.
ai-an7:66.11.4_0: Those who totally understood Sunetta’s teachings were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, the company of Brahmā.
ai-an7:66.11.5_0: Of those who didn’t totally understand Sunetta’s teachings, some—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in the company of the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others. Some were reborn in the company of the Gods Who Love to Create, some with the Joyful Gods, some with the Gods of Yama, some with the Gods of the Thirty-Three, and some with the Gods of the Four Great Kings. Some were reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders.
ai-an7:66.12.2_0: ‘It’s not proper for me to be reborn in the next life in exactly the same place as my disciples. Why don’t I further develop love?’
ai-an7:66.13.1_0: Then Sunetta developed love for seven years.
ai-an7:66.13.2_0: Having done so he did not return to this world for seven eons of cosmic expansion and contraction.
ai-an7:66.13.3_0: As the cosmos contracted he went to the realm of streaming radiance.
ai-an7:66.13.4_0: As it expanded he was reborn in an empty mansion of Brahmā.
ai-an7:66.13.5_0: There he was Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the undefeated, the champion, the universal seer, the wielder of power.
ai-an7:66.13.6_0: He was Sakka, lord of gods, thirty-six times.
ai-an7:66.13.7_0: Many hundreds of times he was a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extended to all four sides, he achieved stability in the country, and he possessed the seven treasures.
ai-an7:66.13.8_0: He had over a thousand sons who were valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
ai-an7:66.13.9_0: After conquering this land girt by sea, I reigned by principle, without rod or sword.
ai-an7:66.13.10_0: Yet even though Sunetta lived so long, he was not exempt from
ai-an7:66.13.11_0: rebirth, old age, and death. He was not exempt from sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and despair, I say.
ai-an7:66.14.2_0: Because of not understanding and not penetrating four things.
ai-an7:66.14.4_0: Noble ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom.
ai-an7:66.14.5_0: These noble ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the attachment to continued existence is ended; now there’ll be no more future lives.”
ai-an7:66.14.6_0: This is what the Buddha said.

ai-an7:66.16.3_0: The Teacher has made an end of suffering;
ai-an7:67.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a king’s frontier citadel is well provided with seven essentials and gets four kinds of sustenance when needed, without trouble or difficulty,
ai-an7:67.1.2_0: This is called the citadel with something more than that.
ai-an7:67.2.1_0: With what seven essentials is a citadel well provided?
ai-an7:67.2.2_0: Firstly, a citadel has a pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.
ai-an7:67.2.3_0: This is the first essential with which a king’s frontier citadel is well provided, to defend those within and repel those outside.
ai-an7:67.3.1_0: Furthermore, a citadel has a moat that is deep and wide.
ai-an7:67.4.1_0: Furthermore, a citadel has a patrol path that is high and wide.
ai-an7:67.5.1_0: Furthermore, a citadel has stores of many weapons, both projectile and hand-held.
ai-an7:67.6.1_0: Furthermore, many kinds of armed forces reside in a citadel, such as
ai-an7:67.6.2_0: elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.
ai-an7:67.7.1_0: Furthermore, a citadel has a gatekeeper who is astute, competent, and intelligent. He keeps strangers out and lets known people in.
ai-an7:67.8.1_0: Furthermore, a citadel has a wall that’s high and wide, covered with plaster.
ai-an7:67.8.2_0: This is the seventh essential with which a king’s frontier citadel is well provided, to defend those within and repel those outside.
ai-an7:67.8.3_0: With these seven essentials a citadel is well provided.
ai-an7:67.9.1_0: What are the four kinds of sustenance it gets when needed, without trouble or difficulty?
ai-an7:67.9.2_0: Firstly, a king’s frontier citadel has much hay, wood, and water stored up for the enjoyment, relief, and comfort of those within and to repel those outside.
ai-an7:67.10.1_0: Furthermore, a king’s frontier citadel has much rice and barley stored up for those within.
ai-an7:67.11.1_0: Furthermore, a king’s frontier citadel has much food such as sesame, green gram, and black gram stored up for those within.
ai-an7:67.12.1_0: Furthermore, a king’s frontier citadel has much medicine—
ai-an7:67.12.2_0: ghee, butter, oil, honey, molasses, and salt—stored up for the enjoyment, relief, and comfort of those within and to repel those outside.
ai-an7:67.12.3_0: These are the four kinds of sustenance it gets when needed, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-an7:67.13.1_0: When a king’s frontier citadel is well provided with seven essentials and gets four kinds of sustenance when needed, without trouble or difficulty,
ai-an7:67.13.2_0: This is called the citadel with something more than that.
ai-an7:67.13.3_0: In the same way, when a noble disciple has seven good qualities, and they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty,
ai-an7:67.13.4_0: they are then called a noble disciple who cannot be overrun by Māra, who cannot be overrun by the Wicked One.
ai-an7:67.13.5_0: What are the seven good qualities that they have?
ai-an7:67.14.1_0: Just as a king’s frontier citadel has a pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable, to defend those within and repel those outside,
ai-an7:67.14.2_0: in the same way a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:
ai-an7:67.14.3_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-an7:67.14.4_0: A noble disciple with faith as their pillar gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful,
ai-an7:67.14.7_0: This is the first good quality they have.
ai-an7:67.15.1_0: Just as a citadel has a moat that is deep and wide,
ai-an7:67.15.2_0: in the same way a noble disciple has a conscience. They’re conscientious about bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and conscientious about having any bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-an7:67.15.3_0: A noble disciple with a conscience as their moat gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful,
ai-an7:67.15.6_0: This is the second good quality they have.
ai-an7:67.16.1_0: Just as a citadel has a patrol path that is high and wide,
ai-an7:67.16.2_0: in the same way a noble disciple is prudent. They’re prudent when it comes to bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and prudent when it comes to acquiring any bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-an7:67.16.3_0: A noble disciple with prudence as their patrol path gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful,
ai-an7:67.16.6_0: This is the third good quality they have.
ai-an7:67.17.1_0: Just as a citadel has stores of many weapons, both projectile and hand-held,
ai-an7:67.17.2_0: in the same way a noble disciple is very learned. They remember and keep what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-an7:67.17.3_0: A noble disciple with learning as their weapon gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful,
ai-an7:67.17.6_0: This is the fourth good quality they have.
ai-an7:67.18.1_0: Just as many kinds of armed forces reside in a citadel ...
ai-an7:67.18.2_0: elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and those within and outside.
ai-an7:67.18.3_0: in the same way a noble disciple is energetic. They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
ai-an7:67.18.4_0: A noble disciple with energy as their armed forces gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful,
ai-an7:67.18.7_0: This is the fifth good quality they have.
ai-an7:67.19.1_0: Just as a citadel has a gatekeeper who is astute, competent, and intelligent, who keeps strangers out and lets known people in,
ai-an7:67.19.2_0: in the same way a noble disciple is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
ai-an7:67.19.3_0: A noble disciple with mindfulness as their gatekeeper gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful,
ai-an7:67.19.6_0: This is the sixth good quality they have.
ai-an7:67.20.1_0: Just as a citadel has a wall that’s high and wide, covered with plaster, to defend those within and repel those outside,
ai-an7:67.20.2_0: in the same way a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an7:67.20.3_0: A noble disciple with wisdom as their wall gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful,
ai-an7:67.20.6_0: This is the seventh good quality they have.
ai-an7:67.20.7_0: These are the seven good qualities that they have.
ai-an7:67.21.1_0: And what are the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty?
ai-an7:67.21.2_0: Just as a king’s frontier citadel has much hay, wood, and water stored up,
ai-an7:67.21.3_0: in the same way a noble disciple, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-an7:67.21.4_0: are for the sake of themselves, for the sake of comfort and for alighting upon extinguishment.
ai-an7:67.22.1_0: Just as a king’s frontier citadel has much rice and barley stored up,
ai-an7:67.22.2_0: in the same way, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a noble disciple enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-an7:67.22.3_0: are for the sake of themselves, for the sake of comfort and for alighting upon extinguishment.
ai-an7:67.23.1_0: Just as a king’s frontier citadel has much food such as sesame, green gram, and black gram stored up,
ai-an7:67.23.2_0: in the same way with the fading away of rapture, a noble disciple enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
ai-an7:67.23.3_0: are for the sake of themselves, for the sake of comfort and for alighting upon extinguishment.
ai-an7:67.24.1_0: Just as a king’s frontier citadel has much medicine—

ai-an7:68.1.1_0: “A mendicant with seven qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods ...
ai-an7:68.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, has self-knowledge, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows people high and low.
ai-an7:68.2.1_0: And how is a mendicant one who knows the teachings?
ai-an7:68.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant knows the teachings:
ai-an7:68.2.3_0: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and classifications.
ai-an7:68.2.4_0: If a mendicant did not know these teachings,
ai-an7:68.2.5_0: they would not be called ‘one who knows the teachings’.
ai-an7:68.2.6_0: But because they do know these teachings,
ai-an7:68.2.7_0: they are called ‘one who knows the teachings’.
ai-an7:68.2.8_0: Such is the one who knows the teachings.
ai-an7:68.3.1_0: And how are they one who knows the meaning?
ai-an7:68.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant knows the meaning of this or that statement:
ai-an7:68.3.3_0: ‘This is what that statement means; that is what this statement means.’
ai-an7:68.3.4_0: If they don’t know the meaning of this or that statement,
ai-an7:68.3.5_0: they would not be called ‘one who knows the meaning’.
ai-an7:68.3.6_0: But because they do know the meaning of this or that statement,
ai-an7:68.3.7_0: they are called ‘one who knows the meaning’.
ai-an7:68.3.8_0: Such is the one who knows the teachings and the one who knows the meaning.
ai-an7:68.4.1_0: And how are they one who has self-knowledge?
ai-an7:68.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has self-knowledge:
ai-an7:68.4.3_0: ‘This is the extent of my faith, ethics, learning, generosity, wisdom, and eloquence.’
ai-an7:68.4.4_0: If a mendicant did not have self-knowledge,
ai-an7:68.4.5_0: they would not be called ‘one who has self-knowledge’.
ai-an7:68.4.6_0: But because they do have self-knowledge,
ai-an7:68.4.7_0: they are called ‘one who has self-knowledge’.
ai-an7:68.4.8_0: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, and the one who has self-knowledge.
ai-an7:68.5.1_0: And how are they one who knows moderation?
ai-an7:68.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant knows moderation when receiving robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-an7:68.5.3_0: If a mendicant did not know moderation, they would not be called ‘one who knows moderation’.
ai-an7:68.5.4_0: But because they do know moderation, they are called ‘one who knows moderation’.
ai-an7:68.5.5_0: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, and the one who knows moderation.
ai-an7:68.6.1_0: And how are they one who knows the right time?
ai-an7:68.6.2_0: It’s when a mendicant knows the right time:
ai-an7:68.6.3_0: ‘This is the time for recitation; this is the time for questioning; this is the time for meditation; this is the time for retreat.’
ai-an7:68.6.4_0: If a mendicant did not know the right time,
ai-an7:68.6.5_0: they would not be called ‘one who knows the right time’.
ai-an7:68.6.6_0: But because they do know the right time,
ai-an7:68.6.7_0: they are called ‘one who knows the right time’.
ai-an7:68.6.8_0: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, and the one who knows moderation.
ai-an7:68.7.1_0: And how are they one who knows assemblies?
ai-an7:68.7.2_0: It’s when a mendicant knows assemblies:
ai-an7:68.7.3_0: ‘This is an assembly of aristocrats, of brahmins, of householders, or of ascetics.
ai-an7:68.7.4_0: This one should be approached in this way. This is how to stand, to act, to sit, to speak, or to stay silent when there.’
ai-an7:68.7.5_0: If a mendicant did not know assemblies,
ai-an7:68.7.6_0: ‘This is an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
ai-an7:68.7.7_0: they would not be called ‘one who knows assemblies’.
ai-an7:68.7.8_0: But because they do know assemblies,
ai-an7:68.7.9_0: ‘This is an assembly of aristocrats, of brahmins, of householders, or of ascetics.
ai-an7:68.7.10_0: they are called ‘one who knows assemblies’.
ai-an7:68.7.11_0: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, the one who knows moderation, the one who knows the right time, and the one who knows assemblies.

ai-an7:69.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when the leaves on the Shady Orchid Tree belonging to the Gods of the Thirty-Three turn brown, the gods are elated. They think:
ai-an7:69.1.2_0: ‘Now the leaves on the Shady Orchid Tree have turned brown! It won’t be long until they fall.’
ai-an7:69.2.1_0: When the leaves have fallen, the gods are elated. They think:
ai-an7:69.2.2_0: ‘Now the leaves on the Shady Orchid Tree have fallen. It won’t be long until its foliage starts to regrow.’
ai-an7:69.3.1_0: When the foliage starts to regrow, the gods are elated. They think:
ai-an7:69.3.2_0: ‘Now the foliage of the Shady Orchid Tree has started to regrow. It won’t be long until it’s ready to grow flowers and leaves separately.’
ai-an7:69.4.1_0: When it’s ready to grow flowers and leaves separately, the gods are elated. They think:
ai-an7:69.4.2_0: ‘Now the Shady Orchid Tree is ready to grow flowers and leaves separately. It won’t be long until buds start to form.’
ai-an7:69.5.1_0: When the buds start to form, the gods are elated. They think:
ai-an7:69.5.2_0: ‘Now the buds of the Shady Orchid Tree have started to form. It won’t be long until the buds burst.’
ai-an7:69.6.1_0: When the buds have burst, the gods are elated. They think:
ai-an7:69.6.2_0: ‘Now the buds of the Shady Orchid Tree have burst. It won’t be long until it fully blossoms.’
ai-an7:69.7.1_0: When the Shady Orchid Tree of the Gods of the Thirty-Three has fully blossomed, the gods are elated. For four heavenly months they amused themselves at the root of the tree, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-an7:69.8.1_0: When the Shady Orchid Tree has fully blossomed, its radiance spreads for fifty leagues, while its fragrance wafts for a hundred leagues. Such is the majesty of the Shady Orchid Tree.
ai-an7:69.9.1_0: In the same way, when a noble disciple plans to go forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its leaves turn brown.
ai-an7:69.10.1_0: When a noble disciple shaves off their hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its leaves fall.
ai-an7:69.11.1_0: When a noble disciple, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected,
ai-an7:69.11.2_0: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its buds burst.
ai-an7:69.12.1_0: When, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a noble disciple enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected,
ai-an7:69.12.2_0: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when it’s ready to grow flowers and leaves separately.
ai-an7:69.13.1_0: When, with the fading away of rapture, a noble disciple enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss’,
ai-an7:69.13.2_0: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its buds start to form.
ai-an7:69.14.1_0: When, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a noble disciple enters and remains in the cessation of suffering,
ai-an7:69.14.1_1: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-an7:69.14.2_0: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its buds burst.
ai-an7:69.15.1_0: When a noble disciple realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements,
ai-an7:69.15.2_0: they’re like the Shady Orchid tree when it fully blossoms.
ai-an7:69.16.1_0: At that time the earth gods raised the cry:
ai-an7:69.16.2_0: ‘That Venerable so-and-so has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness. Having realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
ai-an7:69.16.3_0: Hearing the earth gods, the gods of the four great kings, the Tāvatiṁsa gods cried out ...
ai-an7:69.16.7_0: the gods who delight in creation ...
ai-an7:69.16.8_0: the gods who control the creation of others ...
ai-an7:69.16.9_0: the Gods of Brahmā’s Host raised the cry:
ai-an7:69.16.10_0: ‘That Venerable so-and-so has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness. Having realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
ai-an7:69.16.11_0: And so in a moment, in an instant, the sound soared up to the Brahmā realm.”
